questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents to you with intellectual disability and hearing loss and you notice the following external ear anomaly. What could be the anomaly in this case be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preauricular Tag

 

  • The external ear anomaly visible in the image is a preauricular tag (preauricular appendage), which is a congenital external ear anomaly. It appears as a skin-covered piece of cartilage located anywhere between the tragus and the angle of the mouth. 
  • These tags arise due to abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches during embryogenesis.
  • Preauricular tags are commonly associated with syndromes such as Goldenhar syndrome, which presents with:
  • Facial asymmetry
  • Hearing loss
  • Preauricular skin tags

 

Other Options:


Option A. Ganglion: A ganglion is a fluid-filled cystic swelling that typically arises from tendons or joint capsules rather than the external ear.

 

  • It is not congenital and is not associated with hearing loss or intellectual disability.

 

 

Option B. Preauricular Sinus: A preauricular sinus is a small pit or opening near the anterior margin of the ear, which may lead to a subcutaneous tract.

 

  • Unlike a preauricular tag, it does not appear as a raised cartilage-like mass.
  • It is associated with recurrent infections rather than syndromic conditions.

 

 

Option D. Neurodermatitis: Neurodermatitis (lichen simplex chronicus) is a chronic skin condition caused by repeated scratching, leading to thickened, lichenified plaques. It is not congenital and does not appear as an isolated external ear anomaly.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preauricular tags are congenital external ear anomalies that may be isolated or syndromic (e.g., Goldenhar syndrome). Any newborn with external ear anomalies should undergo hearing screening and evaluation for associated syndromes, as these anomalies may indicate underlying structural or genetic conditions affecting craniofacial development.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 51

choices.text: Incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing
Immediate referral for plastic surgery consultation

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen left ear following a physical altercation. On examination, the left auricle is markedly swollen and deformed with a fluctuant, non-erythematous area occupying most of the antihelical fold. There is no laceration or discharge, and the patient denies any hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and Drainage Followed by Pressure Dressing

 

The given case describes a 22-year-old male with a swollen, fluctuant auricle following trauma, which is characteristic of an auricular hematoma.

 

  • Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma leading to blood accumulation between the perichondrium and auricular cartilage.
  • The best management is incision and drainage (I&D) followed by a pressure dressing to:
    • Evacuate the hematoma and prevent re-accumulation.
    • Maintain blood supply to the cartilage and prevent necrosis.
    • Minimize the risk of "cauliflower ear" deformity (fibrotic, deformed auricle due to chronic hematoma).

 

Procedure:

 

  1. Local anesthesia is administered.
  2. Small incision or needle aspiration to drain the hematoma.
  3. Pressure dressing is applied to prevent hematoma reformation.
  4. Antibiotics (to prevent perichondritis) may be prescribed in some cases.
  5. Follow-up is necessary to check for recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cold Compress and Analgesics: Incorrect because symptomatic treatment alone does not evacuate the hematoma. Persistent blood accumulation can cause cartilage necrosis and fibrosis, leading to a cauliflower ear deformity.

 

Option C. Oral Antibiotics and Outpatient Follow-up: Incorrect because auricular hematoma is not primarily an infection but a traumatic blood collection. Oral antibiotics do not treat the underlying hematoma, though they may be used to prevent secondary perichondritis.

 

Option D. Immediate Referral for Plastic Surgery Consultation: Incorrect because plastic surgery is not the first-line intervention for an uncomplicated auricular hematoma. Most cases are managed in the emergency or ENT department with incision, drainage, and dressing. Plastic surgery is considered only in cases of failed initial treatment or severe deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Auricular hematomas should be managed promptly with incision and drainage followed by a pressure dressing to prevent cartilage necrosis and permanent deformity (cauliflower ear). 
  • Cold compresses, antibiotics, or plastic surgery consultation alone are not sufficient initial treatments.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

choices.text: Ear cartilage has reached full adult size.
Prevention of psychological distress from peer teasing.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a pinnaplasty due to prominent ears. The parents inquire about the rationale for choosing this age for the procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate reason for performing pinnaplasty at this age?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the Above

 

  • Pinnaplasty (also called Otoplasty) is a surgical procedure performed to correct prominent ears for both functional and cosmetic reasons. The ideal age for the surgery is around 6 years, due to the following key factors:

 

Option A. Ear cartilage has reached near adult size: By age 6, the external ear has grown to about 85–90% of its adult size. Performing the surgery at this stage ensures that reshaping is accurate and stable with minimal future changes.

 

Option B. Chondral cartilage is mature enough for reshaping: At this age, the cartilage is flexible yet strong, making it easier to reshape and maintain the new position postoperatively. If done earlier, the cartilage may be too soft and prone to deformation, while delaying the procedure might reduce cartilage malleability.

 

Option C. Prevention of psychological distress from peer teasing: Children often start school around this age, and prominent ears can lead to teasing, bullying, and psychological distress.  Early correction helps improve self-esteem and confidence before negative social experiences occur.

 

  • Because all these factors contribute to the decision for surgery, option D (All of the Above) is the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pinnaplasty (Otoplasty) is ideally performed at around 6 years of age because:
    • The external ear has reached near-adult size (~85–90%).
    • The cartilage is mature yet flexible enough for reshaping.
    • Psychological distress from peer teasing can be prevented.
      A combination of these factors makes 6 years the optimal time for the procedure.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with a three-day history of pain and swelling in his right ear. He has no significant past medical history but recalls scratching his ear with a toothpick a few days ago. On examination, the right pinna is erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch, especially around the cartilage. There is no discharge or fluctuance, and the auditory canal appears normal. The tympanic membrane is intact and mobile. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral Antibiotics and Analgesics

 

  • The clinical presentation of erythema, swelling, and tenderness localized to the auricular cartilage without fluctuance suggests perichondritis—a bacterial infection of the auricular cartilage commonly caused by trauma (e.g., scratching with a toothpick).
  • Most Common Pathogen: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Other Possible Pathogens: Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species
  • Management: 
  • Oral antibiotics (fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin) to cover Pseudomonas and other bacterial causes.
  • Analgesics to relieve inflammation-related pain.
  • If abscess formation occurs, incision and drainage may be needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Antivirals and Analgesics: Incorrect, because viral infections (e.g., herpes zoster oticus/Ramsay Hunt syndrome) do not cause isolated cartilage inflammation. Herpes zoster oticus would present with vesicular rash, facial nerve palsy, and otalgia, which are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Incision and Drainage: Incorrect, because incision and drainage are only indicated if there is abscess formation. This case lacks fluctuance, meaning there is no abscess—only diffuse inflammation of the cartilage.

 

Early perichondritis is treated conservatively with antibiotics before an abscess develops. 

 

Option D. Topical Antibiotic Ear Drops: Incorrect, because topical antibiotic ear drops are only effective for otitis externa (infection of the external auditory canal), not perichondritis. Perichondritis requires systemic antibiotics as the infection is deeper and involves cartilage, not just the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage, commonly occurring after trauma and often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Early recognition and treatment with systemic antibiotics (fluoroquinolones) are crucial to prevent cartilage necrosis and auricular deformity. Incision and drainage are reserved for abscess formation, and topical antibiotics are ineffective for deep cartilage infections.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

choices.text: Surgical Excision of the Sinus Tract

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a small pit near her right ear, which has been present since birth. On examination, a small opening is noted anterior to the ascending limb of the helix of the right ear. There is no redness, swelling, or drainage at the time of the visit. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Observation and Hygiene Education

 

The clinical presentation is consistent with a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly resulting from an incomplete fusion of the first and second branchial arches.

 

  • Preauricular sinuses are typically asymptomatic and do not require surgical intervention unless they become infected or recurrently symptomatic.
  • Best initial management: 
    • Observation for signs of infection (redness, swelling, or discharge).
    • Hygiene education: Patients should be advised to keep the area clean to reduce the risk of infection.
    • Medical attention should be sought if signs of infection appear.

 

Development of Preauricular Sinus:

 

  • The external ear develops from six hillocks of His, derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches.
  • Defective fusion between the first and second arch leads to preauricular sinus formation, usually located above the tragus or at the root of the helix.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgical Excision of the Sinus Tract: Incorrect, because surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or infected cases. Performing surgery on an asymptomatic patient is unnecessary and may lead to complications such as scarring or recurrence if not completely removed.

 

Option B. Topical Antibiotic Ointment Application: Incorrect, because there is no active infection or drainage, making antibiotics unnecessary. Topical antibiotics are used only when there is localized infection, such as mild erythema or purulent discharge.

 

Option C. Systemic Antibiotics: Incorrect, because systemic antibiotics are indicated only in cases of acute infection with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, cellulitis). In an asymptomatic preauricular sinus, antibiotics offer no benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A preauricular sinus is a congenital defect resulting from incomplete fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches. 
  • Asymptomatic cases require only observation and hygiene education. Surgical excision and antibiotics are reserved for infected or recurrently symptomatic cases.

 

Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

choices.text: Potential for spread of infection from the TMJ to the ear
Abnormality leading to conductive hearing loss

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) pain and occasional otorrhea, especially after chewing. Examination reveals a small opening in the antero-inferior part of the bony ear canal. This anatomical variation is known as the foramen of Huschke. What is the most likely clinical significance of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potential for spread of infection from the TMJ to the Ear

 

The foramen of Huschke is a congenital defect in the antero-inferior portion of the bony external auditory canal (EAC). This persisting defect creates a communication between the EAC and the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

 

  • Clinical significance: 
  • It allows infection or inflammation from the TMJ to spread into the external ear, leading to otorrhea and ear discomfort.
  • Patients may present with TMJ pain, clicking sounds, or ear discharge that worsens with jaw movement (e.g., chewing).
  • In some cases, herniation of soft tissues from the TMJ into the ear canal can occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of Cholesteatoma formation: Incorrect, because cholesteatomas arise due to chronic middle ear infections, tympanic membrane retraction, or Eustachian tube dysfunction. The foramen of Huschke does not contribute directly to cholesteatoma formation.

 

Option C. Abnormality leading to conductive hearing loss: Incorrect, because the foramen of Huschke does not typically affect the ossicles or tympanic membrane, which are the main structures involved in conductive hearing loss.

Conductive hearing loss is more commonly due to middle ear infections, otosclerosis, or ossicular chain dysfunction.

 

Option D. Increased risk of Otosclerosis: Incorrect, because otosclerosis is a disease affecting the stapes footplate in the middle ear, leading to progressive conductive hearing loss. The foramen of Huschke has no role in otosclerosis development. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The foramen of Huschke is a congenital defect in the antero-inferior bony external auditory canal that creates a communication between the TMJ and the ear.
  • This can lead to the spread of TMJ infections to the ear, causing otorrhea, ear pain, and symptoms that worsen with chewing.

 

Ref. P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 2.

choices.text: Arnold's Nerve (a branch of the Vagus Nerve)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a laceration on the upper part of his left ear following a minor car accident. He reports numbness in the area surrounding the laceration. On examination, the laceration involves the helix but does not extend to the external auditory canal. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Greater Auricular Nerve

 

  • The Greater Auricular Nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and provides sensory innervation to most of the auricle (pinna) and the skin behind the ear.
  • Key anatomical significance:
    • It emerges from the cervical plexus and ascends over the sternocleidomastoid muscle to innervate the lower two-thirds of the auricle, including the helix, antihelix, and lobule.
    • Injury to this nerve, such as from a laceration to the helix, can result in numbness of the affected area.
  • Why is it the most likely affected nerve?
    • The helix is primarily innervated by the Greater Auricular Nerve.
    • The numbness around the laceration is explained by injury to the sensory supply of this nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesser Occipital Nerve: Incorrect, because the lesser occipital nerve (C2) innervates the skin over the mastoid process, posterior scalp, and upper neck. It does not provide primary sensation to the helix, making it less likely to be involved in this injury.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: Incorrect, because the auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).

 

  • It supplies sensation to the anterosuperior portion of the external ear, external auditory meatus, and part of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).
  • Also supplies anterior half of outer surface of tympanic membrane
  • The posterior helix is not innervated by this nerve.

 

Option D. Arnold's Nerve (Auricular Branch of the Vagus Nerve): Incorrect, because Arnold’s nerve provides sensation to the external auditory canal posterior wall and concha.

 

  • Also supplies posterior half of outer surface of tympanic membrane
  • It does not supply the helix, making it unlikely to be affected in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Greater Auricular Nerve (C2, C3) is the primary sensory nerve for most of the external ear, including the helix and lobule.
  • Injury to this nerve during trauma can cause numbness in these regions.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve, lesser occipital nerve, and Arnold’s nerve provide sensation to other parts of the ear but do not primarily supply the helix.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 4.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for a routine check-up. The parents express concern about the shape of the child's ears, which they describe as small and underdeveloped. On examination, the child's ears are noted to be smaller than normal with poorly formed helices and lobules, resembling a peanut shape. The child has normal hearing. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with this ear deformity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microtia

 

Microtia is a congenital deformity of the external ear (pinna) where the ear is underdeveloped. The "peanut ear" appearance is a classic descriptor for the small and malformed auricle seen in microtia.

 

  • Most cases of microtia are unilateral, but bilateral cases can occur.
  • Hearing is often normal if the external auditory canal and middle ear structures are unaffected.
  • It may occur as an isolated condition or be associated with other craniofacial syndromes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner Syndrome: Incorrect, because Turner syndrome (45, XO) is characterized by:  Short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, and lymphedema. Hearing loss due to middle ear anomalies and frequent otitis media. Peanut ear is not a typical feature of Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. Treacher Collins Syndrome: Incorrect, because Treacher Collins syndrome is a craniofacial disorder involving:  Hypoplastic zygomatic bones, lower eyelid colobomas, and mandibular hypoplasia. Malformed ears with possible atresia of the external auditory canal, leading to conductive hearing loss. Treacher Collins syndrome causes more severe ear deformities than peanut ear.

 

Option C. Down Syndrome: Incorrect, because Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) presents with:  Small, overfolded ears that are set lower than usual. Distinctive facial features like epicanthal folds, single palmar crease, and intellectual disability. Peanut ear is not characteristic of Down syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "peanut ear" deformity, characterized by small, underdeveloped ears with poorly formed helices and lobules, is most commonly associated with microtia. 
  • Microtia is a congenital external ear malformation that can range in severity and may be associated with other craniofacial anomalies or occur in isolation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 48.

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the sinus
Surgical excision of the sinus tract

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the clinic with pain and swelling in front of her left ear. She has a history of a small pit in that area since birth but has never had any problems until now. On examination, there is erythema, tenderness, and swelling anterior to the tragus of the left ear, and a small amount of purulent discharge is noted from a pit in the same region. There is no fever or hearing loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic Antibiotics Targeting Skin Flora

 

  • The clinical presentation is consistent with an infected preauricular sinus. 
  • A preauricular sinus is a congenital defect resulting from incomplete fusion of the first and second pharyngeal arches, leading to a small pit or sinus anterior to the tragus. 
  • These sinuses can remain asymptomatic but may become infected due to trapped debris or bacterial colonization.
  • Most Common Pathogens:
    • Staphylococcus aureus
    • Streptococcus species
    • Gram-negative bacteria (in some cases)
  • First-line treatment:
    • Systemic antibiotics to target common skin flora and prevent further infection spread.
    • Pain management with NSAIDs or acetaminophen.
    • Incision and drainage only if abscess formation occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage of the Sinus: Incorrect, because incision and drainage are reserved for cases with abscess formation (fluctuant swelling).

 

This patient has erythema and purulent discharge but no fluctuance, making systemic antibiotics the first step.

 

Option C.  Topical Antibiotic Ointment Application: Incorrect, because topical antibiotics alone are not sufficient for deep-seated infections like this.

 

The presence of cellulitis around the sinus suggests a spreading infection that requires systemic therapy.

 

Option D. Surgical Excision of the Sinus Tract: Incorrect, because surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or persistent infections. Performing surgery in an actively infected sinus increases the risk of complications such as poor wound healing or recurrence. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate initial management for an infected preauricular sinus is systemic antibiotics targeting common skin flora (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp.). Surgical excision is reserved for recurrent or complicated cases. Incision and drainage are needed only in cases of abscess formation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 49.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of a progressively enlarging, raised scar on her left earlobe following a piercing six months ago. On examination, the lesion is firm, rubbery, and larger than the original wound, extending beyond the borders of the initial piercing site. The patient reports that the lesion is occasionally itchy and painful. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intralesional Corticosteroid Injections

 

The clinical presentation is consistent with a keloid, which is a pathological overgrowth of scar tissue beyond the original wound margin. Keloids are common after ear piercings and result from excessive collagen deposition and abnormal wound healing.

 

  • First-line treatment: Intralesional corticosteroid injections (e.g., triamcinolone acetonide). 
  • Reduce inflammation, pruritus, and scar size.
  • Inhibit fibroblast proliferation and collagen synthesis.
  • Multiple injections (every 3–4 weeks) are often required for optimal results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical Antibiotics: Incorrect, because keloids are not caused by infection but by an abnormal fibrotic response. Topical antibiotics have no role in modifying excessive collagen deposition.

 

Option C. Surgical Excision: Incorrect as first-line therapy, because surgical excision alone has a high recurrence rate (~50–100%). If surgery is performed, it must be combined with adjuvant treatments (e.g., steroid injections, radiation therapy, pressure therapy) to reduce recurrence.

 

Option D. Application of Silicone Gel Sheets: Incorrect as monotherapy, because silicone gel sheets are more effective for preventing keloid formation rather than treating established keloids. They can be used as an adjunct but are not as effective as corticosteroid injections for active keloids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids are hypertrophic scars that extend beyond the original wound margins due to excessive collagen deposition.
  • First-line treatment includes intralesional corticosteroid injections, which help reduce size, inflammation, and pruritus.
  • Surgical excision has a high recurrence rate unless combined with adjunctive therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a painful, swollen left ear. He has a history of ear piercing two weeks ago. On examination, the upper part of the ear is erythematous, tender, and edematous, with sparing of the earlobe. The external auditory canal and tympanic membrane are normal. Which microorganism is most commonly responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

 

This patient presents with perichondritis, an infection of the auricular cartilage, typically occurring after trauma or ear piercing.

 

  • Most common causative organism: Pseudomonas aeruginosa
    • Thrives in moist environments, including the cartilaginous portion of the external ear.
    • Can cause rapid cartilage destruction if untreated.
  • Key clinical features of perichondritis:
    • Painful swelling and redness of the cartilaginous part of the auricle.
    • Earlobe is spared (differentiating it from cellulitis).
    • History of trauma, piercing, or burns.
    • May progress to abscess formation, requiring incision and drainage.
  • Treatment:
    • Systemic antibiotics covering Pseudomonas (e.g., Ciprofloxacin).
    • Incision and drainage if abscess develops.
    • Analgesics for symptom relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Staphylococcus Aureus

 

  • Incorrect, because while Staphylococcus aureus is a common skin pathogen, it is not the most common cause of perichondritis.
    • S. aureus is more commonly associated with cellulitis, furuncles, and abscesses.

 

Option C: Aspergillus Niger

 

  • Incorrect, because Aspergillus niger is a fungal pathogen that causes otomycosis, an infection of the external auditory canal.
    • Otomycosis presents with black fungal debris, itching, and mild pain, not with erythematous, swollen cartilage.

Option D: Streptococcus Pyogenes

 

  • Incorrect, because Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) causes cellulitis, erysipelas, and pharyngitis, but is not the most common cause of perichondritis.
    • Unlike perichondritis, cellulitis involves the earlobe as well.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular cartilage, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, particularly following ear piercing or trauma. 
  • The earlobe is typically spared, distinguishing it from cellulitis. Prompt antibiotic treatment with fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) is essential to prevent cartilage necrosis and ear deformity.

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 50.

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presents with recurrent infections characterized by drainage from an opening in the neck just below and behind the angle of the mandible and another opening in the external auditory canal. These findings are consistent with a collaural fistula, an abnormality of the first branchial cleft. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical Excision of the Fistula

 

A collaural fistula is a branchial cleft anomaly resulting from incomplete closure of the first branchial cleft during embryogenesis. The fistula has two openings:

 

  • One near the external auditory canal (or middle ear)
  • Another near the angle of the mandible
  • These persistent fistulous tracts can become infected repeatedly, leading to chronic drainage.
  • Definitive treatment requires complete surgical excision to prevent recurrent infections.
  • The fistula runs close to the facial nerve, so meticulous surgical dissection is necessary to avoid nerve injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotic Therapy and Observation: Incorrect, because antibiotics can help treat acute infections but do not cure the underlying congenital anomaly. Without surgical excision, recurrent infections are inevitable.

 

Option C. Corticosteroid Therapy: Incorrect, because steroids are used for inflammatory or autoimmune conditions, not for congenital anomalies like branchial cleft fistulas. Steroids will not prevent infection or close the abnormal tract.

 

Option D. Hearing Assessment and Rehabilitation: Incorrect, because while hearing evaluation may be necessary if middle ear involvement is suspected, it is not the primary treatment. Surgical correction of the fistula is the definitive management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A collaural fistula, a first branchial cleft anomaly, requires surgical excision to prevent recurrent infections and complications. 
  • Antibiotics may be used to treat acute infections, but they do not provide a definitive cure. 
  • The fistula runs near the facial nerve, requiring careful surgical dissection to avoid nerve damage.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 50-51.

choices.text: Neural crest cells from the first pharyngeal arch
Mesoderm of the second pharyngeal arch
Ectodermal hillocks of the first and second pharyngeal arches
Endodermal contributions from the first pharyngeal pouch

questions.text: During embryonic development, the pinna (auricle) forms from contributions of specific embryonic structures. Which of the following correctly identifies the embryonic origin of the pinna?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ectodermal Hillocks of the First and Second Pharyngeal Arches

 

  • The pinna (auricle) develops from six mesenchymal proliferations known as the hillocks of His, which arise from ectodermal tissue surrounding the first and second pharyngeal arches. 
  • These hillocks eventually fuse and remodel to form the complex structure of the pinna.
  • Hillocks from the first pharyngeal arch contribute to:
  • Tragus (first hillock)
  • Helical root
  • Hillocks from the second pharyngeal arch contribute to:
  • Rest of the helix
  • Antihelix, concha, and lobule

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural Crest Cells from the First Pharyngeal Arch: Incorrect, because while neural crest cells contribute to craniofacial structures, they do not directly form the pinna. Neural crest cells are involved in skeletal and cartilaginous development, including Meckel’s cartilage (mandible precursor), but the pinna arises from ectodermal hillocks.

 

Option B. Mesoderm of the Second Pharyngeal Arch: Incorrect, because mesoderm contributes to muscles and vasculature of the ear, but the pinna itself forms from ectodermal proliferations. The auricular muscles (intrinsic and extrinsic) develop from mesoderm, but the external ear structure (pinna) is derived from ectoderm.

 

Option D. Endodermal Contributions from the First Pharyngeal Pouch: Incorrect, because the first pharyngeal pouch endoderm contributes to middle ear structures, not the pinna. The first pharyngeal pouch forms the eustachian tube, tympanic cavity, and mastoid air cells, while the pinna originates from ectodermal hillocks. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pinna (auricle) develops from six ectodermal hillocks located around the first and second pharyngeal arches, which fuse and remodel to form the external ear.  
  • The first pharyngeal arch contributes to the tragus and upper helix, while the second pharyngeal arch forms the remaining auricular structures.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 48.

questions.text: A wrestler presents to your OPD with the following ear deformity. What is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Auricular Hematoma

 

  • The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which results from auricular hematoma. 
  • Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma, causing blood accumulation between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium.
  • If left untreated, the blood clots, organizes, and leads to fibrosis and cartilage remodeling, resulting in the typical distorted appearance known as cauliflower ear (also called pugilistic ear or boxer’s ear).

 

It is commonly seen in:

 

  • Wrestlers
  • Boxers
  • Rugby players

 

Management:

 

  1. Early aspiration or incision and drainage under strict aseptic precautions
  2. Application of a pressure dressing to prevent reaccumulation of blood
  3. Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auricular Cyst: Auricular cysts are fluid-filled swellings that arise due to sebaceous gland obstruction or epidermoid cyst formation. They do not cause cartilage deformation like cauliflower ear.

 

 

Option B. Avulsion of Pinna: Avulsion of the pinna refers to complete or partial detachment of the ear due to severe trauma (e.g., accidents, fights, animal bites). The image shows distorted but intact ear structure, making avulsion less likely.

 

 

Option C. External Ear Exostosis: Exostosis refers to abnormal bony growths in the external auditory canal, often due to repeated cold water exposure (surfer’s ear). It does not cause auricular deformity and affects the ear canal, not the pinna.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Auricular hematoma occurs due to blunt trauma, leading to blood accumulation between cartilage and perichondrium. 
  • If untreated, it progresses to cauliflower ear, a permanent deformity. Immediate aspiration, pressure dressing, and prophylactic antibiotics are key to preventing complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A newborn present with the following condition bilaterally and with external auditory canal atresia. Corrective surgery is usually performed at
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 years of age

 

  • The image shows Microtia, a congenital external ear malformation characterized by underdevelopment of the auricle (pinna). 

  • The patient also has external auditory canal atresia, which is commonly associated with Microtia. 

     

Surgical Reconstruction Timeline for Microtia

  • Corrective surgery (pinnaplasty or otoplasty) is ideally performed at 6 years of age because: 
  • The rib cartilage framework required for auricular reconstruction is adequately developed.
  • The child’s ear size is about 80-90% of adult size, improving cosmetic outcomes.
  • Psychological and social benefits arise as the child starts school.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. <1 year of age: Incorrect because the child’s rib cartilage is not sufficiently developed to create a stable ear framework. The auricle is too small, making reconstruction difficult.

 

Option C. Puberty: Incorrect because delaying surgery until puberty may negatively affect the child’s social confidence and emotional well-being. The rib cartilage is still usable before puberty, making early intervention preferable.

 

Option D. Adulthood: Incorrect because waiting until adulthood prolongs psychological distress and increases surgical complexity. Tissue elasticity is reduced, making reconstruction more difficult. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Microtia is a congenital ear anomaly that requires auricular reconstruction, optimally performed between 6 years of age when the ear has grown sufficiently, and rib cartilage is available. 
  • External auditory canal atresia often coexists, requiring bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA) or canaloplasty for hearing rehabilitation.

 

             

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: Patient presents to you with a painful ear swelling, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perichondritis

 

  • Perichondritis presents as a painful, erythematous swelling of the ear, primarily affecting the auricular cartilage while sparing the earlobe (which lacks cartilage). 
  • The inflammation is due to infection of the perichondrium, the layer supplying blood to the cartilage.

 

Common Causes:

 

  • Trauma: 
    • Iatrogenic: Surgical incision, ear piercing, burns.
    • Non-iatrogenic: Lacerations, insect bites, hematoma formation.
  • Extension of infection: 
    • From diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the external auditory canal.
  • Most Common Causative Organism: 
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common).
    • Staphylococcus aureus can also be involved.

 

Management:

 

  • Antibiotics targeting Pseudomonas (Fluoroquinolones such as ciprofloxacin).
  • Drainage if abscess formation occurs.
  • Avoidance of further trauma to prevent cartilage destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis Externa: Otitis externa (swimmer’s ear) presents with ear pain, pruritus, and otorrhea, often exacerbated by pulling on the tragus (tragal sign).

It primarily affects the external auditory canal rather than the auricular cartilage.

 

 

Option B. Cauliflower Ear: Cauliflower ear results from repeated trauma leading to auricular hematoma, which later organizes and fibroses, causing a deformed appearance.

 

 

Option D. Chondrodermatitis Helicis:  A chronic inflammatory condition of the helix or antihelix, presenting as a small, tender, nodular lesion. It is not associated with significant erythema or swelling like perichondritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perichondritis is a painful infection of the auricular cartilage, commonly due to trauma or extension of infection from otitis externa.
  • It is most often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and requires prompt antibiotic therapy to prevent cartilage destruction and deformity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: Which nerve DOES NOT supply the pinna?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Jacobson’s Nerve

 

Jacobson’s nerve (the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, CN IX) does not supply the pinna. Instead, it is primarily responsible for:

 

  • Innervating the middle ear mucosa.

  • Contributing to the tympanic plexus, which supplies the Eustachian tube, mastoid air cells, and medial aspect of the tympanic membrane.

 

Since it has no sensory role in auricular innervation, it is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Greater Auricular Nerve

  • Derived from C2 and C3 (cervical plexus).

    • Provides sensory innervation to: 

      • Lower part of the pinna (lobule and most of the lateral surface).

      • Skin over the mastoid process and angle of the mandible.

    • Incorrect Choice because it is a key contributor to pinna sensation.

 

Option B: Arnold’s Nerve (Auricular branch of the vagus nerve)

  • Arises from cranial nerve X (vagus nerve).

    • Provides sensory innervation to: 

      • External auditory canal - posterior wall.

      • Concha of the auricle.

      • External surface (– posterior half) of the tympanic membrane.

    • Incorrect Choice because it supplies part of the pinna.

 

Option C: Facial Nerve (CN VII)

 

  • Contributes sensory innervation to a small part of the auricle, especially around the external auditory canal (– posterior wall) and concha.

    • Also provides motor innervation to the auricular muscles.

    • Incorrect Choice because it plays a minor role in auricular innervation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pinna receives sensory innervation from multiple nerves, including the greater auricular nerve (C2, C3), Arnold’s nerve (CN X), and facial nerve (CN VII). Jacobson’s nerve (CN IX) is not involved in auricular innervation, as it supplies the middle ear mucosa and tympanic plexus.

 

Reference: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 4

questions.text: IDENTIFY?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peanut Ear

 

The image shows Peanut Ear, a severe form of microtia, where the external ear appears small, folded, and malformed, resembling a peanut shape.

 

It is often associated with external auditory canal anomalies, as well as middle and inner ear malformations.

 

It can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Hearing loss is common, primarily due to aural atresia or middle ear malformations.

 

Treatment involves auricular reconstruction, typically performed at or after 6 years of age for cosmetic and functional restoration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-auricular Appendages: Preauricular appendages (tags) are small, skin-covered pieces of cartilage found anterior to the ear. They result from incomplete fusion of the first and second branchial arches. Unlike peanut ear, they do not cause significant ear deformity or hearing loss.

 

 

Option C. Lop Ear: Lop ear is a milder congenital deformity where the upper part of the ear folds forward, often due to underdevelopment of the antihelical fold.

 

It does not involve gross malformation or significant hearing loss.

 

Unlike peanut ear, the basic ear structure is preserved.

 

 

Option D.  Anotia: Anotia is the complete absence of the external ear (pinna).

 

  • It is the most severe form of microtia, often associated with aural atresia and severe hearing loss. Unlike peanut ear, where some malformed auricular tissue is present, anotia has no external ear structure at all.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peanut ear is a severe form of microtia, characterized by a small, malformed, folded auricle, often associated with external auditory canal, middle ear, and inner ear anomalies leading to hearing loss.
  • Early evaluation and auricular reconstruction (typically at 6 years of age) are important for functional and cosmetic correction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presented with pain and swelling in front of the left ear for 2 days. She had a similar episode in the past 3 yrs. The examination finding is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infected Preauricular Sinus

 

The image shows a swollen, erythematous area in front of the ear, with pus discharge from a small opening, which is characteristic of an infected preauricular sinus.

 

  • Preauricular sinus is a congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete fusion of the hillocks of His, which arise from the 1st and 2nd branchial arches.
  • It typically presents as a small pit-like opening anterior to the tragus, which may be asymptomatic or recurrently infected, as seen in this case.
  • Recurrent infections lead to pain, swelling, and pus discharge, often requiring antibiotics and surgical excision of the sinus tract to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preauricular Lymphadenitis: Lymphadenitis presents as a swollen, tender lymph node in front of the ear, usually secondary to infection of the scalp, face, or ear. It does not have a sinus opening or pus discharge, making it less likely in this case.

 

 

Option B. Infected Parotid Cyst: Parotid cysts arise from the parotid gland and can become secondarily infected, presenting with pain and swelling. However, an infected parotid cyst does not have an external opening with pus discharge, unlike an infected preauricular sinus.

 

 

Option D. Epidermal Inclusion Cyst: Epidermal cysts are slow-growing subcutaneous swellings that may become infected, leading to pain, redness, and pus discharge. However, they are usually found on the scalp, face, or neck rather than at the typical preauricular sinus location. Unlike a preauricular sinus, they lack a congenital opening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A preauricular sinus is a congenital pit-like anomaly caused by defective fusion of the hillocks of His from the 1st and 2nd branchial arches.
  • It can become infected, leading to pain and pus discharge, requiring antibiotics and eventual surgical excision to prevent recurrence.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

choices.text: Rewarming with moist cotton pledgets at a temperature of 38–42°C,
Application of 0.5% silver nitrate soaks for superficial infection,
Immediate surgical debridement of dead tissues

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about treatment of frostbite?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Immediate surgical debridement of dead tissues

 

In frostbite, the goal of treatment is to salvage as much tissue as possible while allowing demarcation of necrotic tissue. Immediate surgical debridement is not recommended because:

 

  • The extent of tissue necrosis is not fully established initially.
  • Early debridement may remove potentially viable tissue.
  • Instead, rewarming, infection control, and supportive care should be prioritized.
  • Surgical intervention is delayed until tissue demarcation is complete (typically after several weeks).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rewarming with moist cotton pledgets at a temperature of 38–42°C: Correct because rapid rewarming with warm water immersion (38–42°C) is the gold standard for treating frostbite. It restores blood flow, reduces ischemia, and prevents further damage. Rewarming should be done gradually, avoiding direct dry heat (e.g., fires, heating pads) to prevent burns.

 

Option B. Application of 0.5% silver nitrate soaks for superficial infection: Correct because topical antiseptics like silver nitrate or povidone-iodine help prevent secondary bacterial infection in frostbitten areas. Frostbite can lead to bullae formation and tissue breakdown, making infection control crucial.

 

Option C. Protection of bullae from rupture: Correct because intact bullae act as a biological dressing, protecting underlying tissues. If clear, they should be left intact; if hemorrhagic, they may require aspiration to relieve pressure. Premature rupture increases infection risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frostbite management involves rapid rewarming, infection prevention, and tissue preservation.
  • Early surgical debridement is avoided to allow for natural tissue demarcation, ensuring only non-viable tissue is removed at a later stage.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49-50

questions.text: A 26yr old female presented with firm, non-tender swelling over the ear since 3yrs which she developed following a second ear piercing.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keloid

 

The image and clinical history suggest keloid, a firm, non-tender overgrowth of scar tissue that extends beyond the original wound margins.

 

  • Etiology: Keloids occur due to excessive collagen deposition in response to skin trauma, such as piercings, burns, or surgical incisions.
  • Common Sites: Auricular lobule and helix, shoulders, chest, and upper back.
  • Pathology: 
    • Contains collagen.
    • Parallel arrangement of collagen fibers.
  • Risk Factors: 
    • Genetic predisposition, more common in Blacks and Asians.
    • Higher risk in areas with high skin tension (shoulders, chest).
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgical excision alone has a high recurrence rate.
    • Intralesional steroid (triamcinolone) and hyaluronidase (enzyme) injections are also used to shrink keloids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Scar: Hypertrophic scars are raised and firm but stay within the boundaries of the original wound, unlike keloids, which extend beyond the wound margins. Contains collagen with a haphazard arrangement.

 

Often self-resolves over time, whereas keloids persist and continue growing.

 

The lesion in the image extends beyond the piercing site, making keloid the correct diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Epidermoid Cyst: Epidermoid cysts are soft, mobile, cystic lesions filled with keratin debris. They often have a central punctum and may become infected, leading to tenderness and discharge. The lesion in the image appears firm and non-tender, which is not characteristic of an epidermoid cyst.

 

 

Option D. Sebaceous Cyst: Sebaceous cysts (pilar cysts) arise from sebaceous glands and are filled with sebum. They are commonly found on the scalp, face, or behind the ear, rather than on the lobule or helix. Unlike keloids, they do not occur due to trauma or piercings.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids are excessive fibrous tissue overgrowths that develop after trauma, burns, or surgery, extending beyond the wound margins.
  • They are common after ear piercings, particularly in individuals with genetic predisposition.
  • Management includes surgical excision combined with steroid injections to prevent recurrence.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 50

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented with complaints of right swollen pinna as shown in the picture since 1 week, that was progressively worsening. Patient had ear piercing 2 weeks ago. Patient was a non-diabetic and in good health, with no other significant past medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perichondritis

 

The image and clinical presentation suggest perichondritis, an infection of the perichondrium (the connective tissue layer that supplies blood to the auricular cartilage).

 

  • Etiology: 
    • Secondary to trauma, such as ear piercing (especially high ear piercings involving the cartilage).
    • May also result from lacerations, hematomas, or surgical incisions.
    • Can spread from diffuse otitis externa or a furuncle of the external auditory canal.
  • Common Pathogens: 
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common).
    • Mixed flora including Staphylococcus aureus may also be involved.
  • Clinical Features: 
    • Red, swollen, painful ear (especially affecting the cartilage).
    • The pinna feels stiff, differentiating it from cellulitis, which involves soft tissues.
    • If untreated, abscess formation occurs between the cartilage and perichondrium, leading to cartilage necrosis and potential ear deformity.

 

Management:

 

  1. Early-stage treatment: 
    • Systemic antibiotics (anti-pseudomonal coverage, e.g., fluoroquinolones or ceftazidime).
  2. If abscess forms:
    • Prompt drainage with incision in the natural fold.
    • Removal of devitalized cartilage.
    • Pus culture and sensitivity-based antibiotics for 7-10 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact Dermatitis: Contact dermatitis presents with itching, redness, and sometimes vesicles, commonly triggered by allergens (e.g., nickel from earrings, hair products, or cosmetics). It does not cause deep inflammation or cartilage involvement. Unlike perichondritis, contact dermatitis is not typically painful or associated with abscess formation.

 

 

Option C. Cellulitis; Cellulitis involves soft tissues rather than cartilage, leading to diffuse swelling, erythema, and warmth. The ear remains soft, unlike perichondritis, where the pinna feels stiff. It is more common in diabetic or immunocompromised patients, while perichondritis occurs in otherwise healthy individuals after trauma or piercing.

 

 

Option D. Otitis Externa: Otitis externa (swimmer’s ear) affects the external auditory canal, presenting with ear pain, pruritus, and discharge.

 

  • The pinna is usually not inflamed, whereas in perichondritis, the pinna is swollen, red, and stiff.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perichondritis is an infection of the auricular perichondrium, often triggered by trauma, ear piercing, or surgery. 
  • It presents with red, swollen, painful, and stiff pinna and is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. 
  • Prompt antibiotic therapy and abscess drainage (if needed) are essential to prevent cartilage necrosis and ear deformity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 50

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the ENT clinic by his parents due to concerns about his ears appearing prominently protruded since birth. Examination reveals a large concha with underdeveloped antihelix and scapha. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bat Ear (Prominent Ear)

 

Bat ear (also called prominent ear or protruding ear) is a congenital auricular deformity where the ear sticks out more than 2 cm from the scalp.

 

This occurs due to: 

 

Large conchal cartilage

 

Poorly developed antihelix and scapha

 

The condition is purely cosmetic and does not affect hearing.

 

Surgical correction (Otoplasty) can be performed after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance concerns the patient or parents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Microtia: Microtia is a congenital malformation of the external ear, characterized by a small, malformed pinna, often associated with aural atresia.

 

The image shows large, protruding but structurally normal ears, ruling out microtia.

 

 

Option C. Cauliflower Ear: Cauliflower ear results from repeated trauma or hematoma formation, leading to cartilage fibrosis and deformity. It is commonly seen in boxers and wrestlers. The boy in the image has smooth and well-defined ears, making cauliflower ear unlikely.

 

 

Option D. Preauricular Tag: Preauricular tags are small, skin-covered cartilage remnants located in front of the tragus. They do not cause the entire ear to protrude and are unrelated to bat ear deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bat ear (Prominent ear) is a congenital condition caused by underdeveloped antihelix and scapha with a large concha, leading to an ear that sticks out excessively.
  • It is purely cosmetic and can be corrected via otoplasty after 6 years of age for psychological and aesthetic concerns.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 48

choices.text: Primary closure with absorbable sutures for perichondrium and nonabsorbable sutures for skin
Immediate debridement with cartilage excision and skin grafting
Leave the wound open to heal by secondary intention
Apply a simple pressure dressing and follow up in one week

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a deep laceration of the left pinna, sustained in a road traffic accident. Examination reveals a complex laceration involving the skin, perichondrium, and cartilage, as seen in the image. What is the best immediate management approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary closure with absorbable sutures for perichondrium and nonabsorbable sutures for skin

 

Lacerations of the ear pinna should be repaired as early as possible to prevent deformity and necrosis.

 

Key steps in management: 

 

  • Perichondrium is stitched with absorbable sutures to maintain cartilage viability.
    • Special care is taken to prevent stripping of the perichondrium from cartilage, as cartilage lacks direct blood supply and depends on perichondrium for nutrition.
    • Skin is closed with fine nonabsorbable sutures to ensure proper healing.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (covering Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus) are given for 1 week to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate debridement with cartilage excision and skin grafting: Incorrect because cartilage should not be excised unnecessarily, as it lacks regenerative capacity. Skin grafting is not the first-line treatment for acute ear lacerations and is only considered in severe avulsion injuries.

 

Option C. Leave the wound open to heal by secondary intention: Incorrect because leaving the wound open may lead to cartilage necrosis, infection, and poor cosmetic outcomes. Primary closure is preferred unless there is severe contamination or devitalized tissue.

 

Option D. Apply a simple pressure dressing and follow up in one week: Incorrect because suturing is necessary to realign the perichondrium and skin for proper healing. A pressure dressing alone is insufficient for deep lacerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ear pinna lacerations require early surgical repair to preserve cartilage viability and prevent deformities. 
  • The perichondrium must be sutured with absorbable sutures, and the skin should be closed with nonabsorbable sutures. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are recommended to prevent infection.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 49

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic with anomalous ear positioning, noticed since birth. Examination reveals that the upper third of the auricle is embedded under the scalp skin, making it difficult for the ear to protrude normally. Based on the clinical image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptotia (Pocket Ear)

 

Cryptotia, also called pocket ear, is a congenital auricular deformity where the upper third of the ear is embedded under the scalp skin, preventing normal ear protrusion.

 

Pathophysiology: The superior auricular cartilage is buried under the temporal skin due to maldevelopment of intrinsic auricular muscles.

 

Clinical Features: 

 

The upper ear cannot be lifted manually due to lack of skin overlying the superior auricular cartilage.

 

The scalp skin is tightly adhered, preventing natural protrusion.

 

Treatment: 

 

Surgical correction involves mobilizing the pinna to its normal position and covering the raw area with a skin graft to allow normal ear contour.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Microtia: Microtia is a congenital anomaly where the external ear is underdeveloped or malformed, often associated with aural atresia. Unlike cryptotia, microtia does not have a normally shaped but buried auricle.

 

 

Option C. Bat Ear (Prominent Ear): Bat ear (Prominent ear) is characterized by an excessively protruding auricle due to a large conchal bowl and underdeveloped antihelix. In contrast, cryptotia is an ear that is buried under the skin, not protruding outward.

 

 

Option D. Lop Ear: Lop ear is a deformity where the upper portion of the auricle bends forward, often due to weak cartilage in the superior helical rim. Unlike cryptotia, the ear is not buried under the scalp skin but simply folded forward.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryptotia (Pocket Ear) is a congenital ear deformity where the upper third of the ear is embedded under the scalp, preventing normal protrusion. 
  • Surgical correction involves mobilizing the ear and performing a skin graft to restore the natural contour.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the ENT clinic for evaluation of an ear deformity noticed at birth. Examination reveals a transverse cleft in the middle of the auricle, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coloboma of the Pinna

 

  • Coloboma of the pinna is a congenital ear anomaly characterized by a transverse cleft in the middle of the auricle, leading to a notch-like defect.
  • It results from improper fusion of the auricular hillocks during embryonic development.
  • Coloboma may be isolated or associated with syndromes like Treacher Collins syndrome.
  • Management: 
    • Mild cases: Cosmetic correction may not be needed.
    • Severe cases: Surgical reconstruction is performed to restore the normal ear contour.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Microtia: Microtia is a condition where the external ear is underdeveloped or malformed, often associated with aural atresia and hearing loss. Unlike coloboma, which presents as a cleft in a normally shaped auricle, microtia involves an entirely malformed pinna.

 

 

Option C. Cryptotia: Cryptotia (Pocket Ear) occurs when the upper third of the ear is buried under the scalp, preventing normal protrusion.In contrast, coloboma has a distinct cleft and is not embedded under the scalp skin.

 

Option D. Preauricular Sinus: Preauricular sinus is a small pit or tract located anterior to the tragus, due to incomplete fusion of the first and second branchial arches. It does not cause a cleft or notching of the pinna, differentiating it from coloboma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coloboma of the pinna is a congenital auricular anomaly presenting as a transverse cleft in the middle of the auricle, due to improper fusion of auricular hillocks.
  • It may be isolated or part of syndromic conditions (e.g., Treacher Collins syndrome).
  • Surgical reconstruction is the treatment of choice for severe cases.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 48

choices.text: Immediate removal of the avulsed segment and skin grafting
Leaving the wound open to heal by secondary intention
Suturing the skin without addressing the cartilage

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, where his external ear was partially torn but still attached by a small pedicle of skin. What is the best management approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary reattachment of the pinna

 

When the pinna is still attached to the head by a small skin pedicle, primary reattachment should be attempted, as it is usually successful.

 

This preserves the natural ear structure and reduces the need for extensive reconstructive procedures later.

 

Steps in management: 

 

  1. Cleaning the wound with sterile saline to remove debris.
  2. Careful realignment of the cartilage with fine absorbable sutures.
  3. Skin closure using nonabsorbable sutures.
  4. Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent secondary infection.
  5. Postoperative monitoring for tissue viability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate removal of the avulsed segment and skin grafting: Incorrect, because if the avulsed segment is partially attached, it should be reattached rather than removed. Skin grafting is only considered if reattachment fails or if the pinna is completely non-viable.

 

Option C. Leaving the wound open to heal by secondary intention: Incorrect, because leaving a large avulsion wound open may lead to: 

 

  • Infection
    • Cartilage necrosis
      • Severe ear deformity
    • Primary closure or reattachment is preferred.

 

Option D. Suturing the skin without addressing the cartilage: Incorrect, because proper reattachment requires realignment of both the skin and cartilage.

 

  • Failure to suture the cartilage properly may lead to: 
    • Cartilage collapse or deformity
      • Hematoma formation and fibrosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pinna avulsion injuries require immediate surgical attention. Primary reattachment should always be attempted if the pinna is partially attached, while microvascular reimplantation may be attempted for complete avulsions. In cases where reimplantation is not possible, cartilage can be implanted under postauricular skin for later reconstruction.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ENT clinic for a routine checkup. On examination, a small, pointed tubercle is seen on the upper part of the helix of his external ear, as indicated by the arrow in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Darwin’s Tubercle

 

Darwin’s Tubercle is a small, pointed, cartilaginous elevation found on the upper part of the helix.

 

It is considered a vestigial remnant of the ear apex seen in lower mammals, serving no functional purpose.

 

It is a normal anatomical variant and does not require treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preauricular Tag: Preauricular tags are small, skin-covered cartilaginous remnants located in front of the tragus (not on the helix). They arise from abnormal fusion of the first and second branchial arches, unlike Darwin’s tubercle, which is a normal variant.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma of Pinna: Coloboma of the pinna is a transverse cleft or notch in the auricle due to auricular maldevelopment. It is a congenital deformity, whereas Darwin’s tubercle is a normal anatomical feature.

 

 

Option D. Keloid: Keloids are raised, firm, hypertrophic scars that occur after trauma, piercings, or surgery. Unlike Darwin’s tubercle, keloids grow beyond the original wound margin and are not a congenital feature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Darwin’s Tubercle is a normal anatomical variant appearing as a small, pointed prominence on the upper helix, representing a vestigial remnant from evolutionary development.
  • It has no clinical significance and does not require treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 48

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the ENT clinic for evaluation of an abnormally shaped ear noticed at birth. Examination reveals that the helix is flat, and the upper crus of the antihelix is duplicated, reaching the rim of the helix. Based on the clinical image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stahl’s Ear

 

Stahl’s ear, also called Spock’s ear or elfin ear, is a congenital auricular deformity characterized by: 

 

Flattening of the helix (instead of the usual curve).

 

Duplication of the upper crus of the antihelix, which extends to the helix.

 

A pointed or triangular shape of the upper ear, giving it an elfin-like appearance.

 

Treatment: 

 

If diagnosed early (within the first 6 weeks of life), a non-surgical molding technique can help reshape the ear.

 

If untreated, surgical correction (otoplasty) may be required later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptotia: Cryptotia (Pocket Ear) occurs when the upper third of the ear is embedded under the scalp, preventing normal protrusion. Unlike Stahl’s ear, cryptotia does not have an extra antihelical fold or a pointed ear shape.

 

 

Option C. Lop Ear: Lop ear is characterized by a downward folding of the upper portion of the ear, due to weak cartilage. In contrast, Stahl’s ear has an extra fold that makes the ear look pointed, not drooping.

 

 

Option D. Microtia: Microtia is a condition where the external ear is underdeveloped or malformed, often associated with aural atresia and hearing loss. Stahl’s ear is not an underdeveloped ear but rather a misfolded auricle with an extra antihelical crus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stahl’s Ear is a congenital auricular deformity caused by abnormal folding of the antihelical cartilage, leading to a pointed or elfin-shaped ear. 
  • Early detection allows molding therapy within the first 6 weeks of life, while surgical correction may be needed later if untreated.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 48
